segment.source: BitLocker How to enable Network Unlock (Windows 10)
segment.target: BitLocker How to enable Network Unlock (Windows 10)

segment.source: This topic for the IT professional describes how BitLocker Network Unlock works and how to configure it.
segment.target: This topic for the IT professional describes how BitLocker Network Unlock works and how to configure it.

segment.source: BitLocker: How to enable Network Unlock
segment.target: BitLocker: How to enable Network Unlock

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: This topic for the IT professional describes how BitLocker Network Unlock works and how to configure it.
segment.target: This topic for the IT professional describes how BitLocker Network Unlock works and how to configure it.

segment.source: Network Unlock was introduced in Windows 8 and Windows Server 2012 as a BitLocker protector option for operating system volumes.
segment.target: Network Unlock was introduced in Windows 8 and Windows Server 2012 as a BitLocker protector option for operating system volumes.

segment.source: Network Unlock enables easier management for BitLocker enabled desktops and servers in a domain environment by providing automatic unlock of operating system volumes at system reboot when connected to a wired corporate network.
segment.target: Network Unlock enables easier management for BitLocker enabled desktops and servers in a domain environment by providing automatic unlock of operating system volumes at system reboot when connected to a wired corporate network.

segment.source: This feature requires the client hardware to have a DHCP driver implemented in its UEFI firmware.
segment.target: This feature requires the client hardware to have a DHCP driver implemented in its UEFI firmware.

segment.source: Without Network Unlock, operating system volumes protected by TPM+PIN protectors require a PIN to be entered when a computer reboots or resumes from hibernation (for example, by Wake on LAN).
segment.target: Without Network Unlock, operating system volumes protected by TPM+PIN protectors require a PIN to be entered when a computer reboots or resumes from hibernation (for example, by Wake on LAN).

segment.source: This can make it difficult to enterprises to roll out software patches to unattended desktops and remotely administered servers.
segment.target: This can make it difficult to enterprises to roll out software patches to unattended desktops and remotely administered servers.

segment.source: Network Unlock allows BitLocker-enabled systems with TPM+PIN and that meet the hardware requirements to boot into Windows without user intervention.
segment.target: Network Unlock allows BitLocker-enabled systems with TPM+PIN and that meet the hardware requirements to boot into Windows without user intervention.

segment.source: Network Unlock works in a similar fashion to the TPM+StartupKey at boot.
segment.target: Network Unlock works in a similar fashion to the TPM+StartupKey at boot.

segment.source: Rather than needing to read the StartupKey from USB media, however, the key for Network Unlock is composed from a key stored in the TPM and an encrypted network key that is sent to the server, decrypted and returned to the client in a secure session.
segment.target: Rather than needing to read the StartupKey from USB media, however, the key for Network Unlock is composed from a key stored in the TPM and an encrypted network key that is sent to the server, decrypted and returned to the client in a secure session.

segment.source: This topic contains:
segment.target: This topic contains:

segment.target: Network Unlock core requirements

segment.target: Network Unlock sequence

segment.target: Configure Network Unlock

segment.target: Create the certificate template for Network Unlock

segment.target: Configure Network Unlock on unsupported systems

segment.source: Network Unlock core requirements
segment.target: Network Unlock core requirements

segment.source: Network Unlock must meet mandatory hardware and software requirements before the feature can automatically unlock domain joined systems.
segment.target: Network Unlock must meet mandatory hardware and software requirements before the feature can automatically unlock domain joined systems.

segment.source: These requirements include:
segment.target: These requirements include:

segment.source: You must be running at least Windows 8 or Windows Server 2012.
segment.target: You must be running at least Windows 8 or Windows Server 2012.

segment.source: Any supported operating system with UEFI DHCP drivers can be Network Unlock clients.
segment.target: Any supported operating system with UEFI DHCP drivers can be Network Unlock clients.

segment.source: A server running the Windows Deployment Services (WDS) role on any supported server operating system.
segment.target: A server running the Windows Deployment Services (WDS) role on any supported server operating system.

segment.source: BitLocker Network Unlock optional feature installed on any supported server operating system.
segment.target: BitLocker Network Unlock optional feature installed on any supported server operating system.

segment.source: A DHCP server, separate from the WDS server.
segment.target: A DHCP server, separate from the WDS server.

segment.source: Properly configured public/private key pairing.
segment.target: Properly configured public/private key pairing.

segment.source: Network Unlock Group Policy settings configured.
segment.target: Network Unlock Group Policy settings configured.

segment.source: The network stack must be enabled to use the Network Unlock feature.
segment.target: The network stack must be enabled to use the Network Unlock feature.

segment.source: Equipment manufacturers deliver their products in various states and with different BIOS menus, so you need to confirm that the network stack has been enabled in the BIOS before starting the computer.
segment.target: Equipment manufacturers deliver their products in various states and with different BIOS menus, so you need to confirm that the network stack has been enabled in the BIOS before starting the computer.

segment.source: Note: To properly support DHCP within UEFI, the UEFI-based system should be in native mode without a compatibility support module (CSM) enabled.
segment.target: Note: To properly support DHCP within UEFI, the UEFI-based system should be in native mode without a compatibility support module (CSM) enabled.

segment.source: For Network Unlock to work reliably on computers running Windows 8 and later, the first network adapter on the computer, usually the onboard adapter, must be configured to support DHCP and used for Network Unlock.
segment.target: For Network Unlock to work reliably on computers running Windows 8 and later, the first network adapter on the computer, usually the onboard adapter, must be configured to support DHCP and used for Network Unlock.

segment.source: This is especially worth noting when you have multiple adapters, and you wish to configure one without DHCP, such as for a lights-out management protocol.
segment.target: This is especially worth noting when you have multiple adapters, and you wish to configure one without DHCP, such as for a lights-out management protocol.

segment.source: This configuration is necessary because Network Unlock will stop enumerating adapters when it reaches one with a DHCP port failure for any reason.
segment.target: This configuration is necessary because Network Unlock will stop enumerating adapters when it reaches one with a DHCP port failure for any reason.

segment.source: Thus, if the first enumerated adapter does not support DHCP, is not plugged into the network, or fails to report availability of the DHCP port for any reason, then Network Unlock will fail.
segment.target: Thus, if the first enumerated adapter does not support DHCP, is not plugged into the network, or fails to report availability of the DHCP port for any reason, then Network Unlock will fail.

segment.source: The Network Unlock server component installs on supported versions of Windows Server 2012 and later as a Windows feature using Server Manager or Windows PowerShell cmdlets.
segment.target: The Network Unlock server component installs on supported versions of Windows Server 2012 and later as a Windows feature using Server Manager or Windows PowerShell cmdlets.

segment.source: The feature name is BitLocker Network Unlock in Server Manager and BitLocker-NetworkUnlock in Windows PowerShell.
segment.target: The feature name is BitLocker Network Unlock in Server Manager and BitLocker-NetworkUnlock in Windows PowerShell.

segment.source: This feature is a core requirement.
segment.target: This feature is a core requirement.

segment.source: Network Unlock requires Windows Deployment Services (WDS) in the environment where the feature will be utilized.
segment.target: Network Unlock requires Windows Deployment Services (WDS) in the environment where the feature will be utilized.

segment.source: Configuration of the WDS installation is not required; however, the WDS service needs to be running on the server.
segment.target: Configuration of the WDS installation is not required; however, the WDS service needs to be running on the server.

segment.source: The network key is stored on the system drive along with an AES 256 session key, and encrypted with the 2048-bit RSA public key of the unlock server's certificate.
segment.target: The network key is stored on the system drive along with an AES 256 session key, and encrypted with the 2048-bit RSA public key of the unlock server's certificate.

segment.source: The network key is decrypted with the help of a provider on a supported version of Windows Server running WDS, and returned encrypted with its corresponding session key.
segment.target: The network key is decrypted with the help of a provider on a supported version of Windows Server running WDS, and returned encrypted with its corresponding session key.

segment.source: Network Unlock sequence
segment.target: Network Unlock sequence

segment.source: The unlock sequence starts on the client side, when the Windows boot manager detects the existence of Network Unlock protector.
segment.target: The unlock sequence starts on the client side, when the Windows boot manager detects the existence of Network Unlock protector.

segment.source: It leverages the DHCP driver in UEFI to obtain an IP address for IPv4 and then broadcasts a vendor-specific DHCP request that contains the network key and a session key for the reply, all encrypted by the server's Network Unlock certificate, as described above.
segment.target: It leverages the DHCP driver in UEFI to obtain an IP address for IPv4 and then broadcasts a vendor-specific DHCP request that contains the network key and a session key for the reply, all encrypted by the server's Network Unlock certificate, as described above.

segment.source: The Network Unlock provider on the supported WDS server recognizes the vendor-specific request, decrypts it with the RSA private key, and returns the network key encrypted with the session key via its own vendor-specific DHCP reply.
segment.target: The Network Unlock provider on the supported WDS server recognizes the vendor-specific request, decrypts it with the RSA private key, and returns the network key encrypted with the session key via its own vendor-specific DHCP reply.

segment.source: On the server side, the WDS server role has an optional plugin component, like a PXE provider, which is what handles the incoming Network Unlock requests.
segment.target: On the server side, the WDS server role has an optional plugin component, like a PXE provider, which is what handles the incoming Network Unlock requests.

segment.source: The provider can also be configured with subnet restrictions, which would require that the IP address provided by the client in the Network Unlock request belong to a permitted subnet in order to release the network key to the client.
segment.target: The provider can also be configured with subnet restrictions, which would require that the IP address provided by the client in the Network Unlock request belong to a permitted subnet in order to release the network key to the client.

segment.source: In instances where the Network Unlock provider is unavailable, BitLocker fails over to the next available protector to unlock the drive.
segment.target: In instances where the Network Unlock provider is unavailable, BitLocker fails over to the next available protector to unlock the drive.

segment.source: In a typical configuration, this means the standard TPM+PIN unlock screen is presented to unlock the drive.
segment.target: In a typical configuration, this means the standard TPM+PIN unlock screen is presented to unlock the drive.

segment.source: The server side configuration to enable Network Unlock also requires provisioning a 2048-bit RSA public/private key pair in the form of an X.509 certificate, and for the public key certificate to be distributed to the clients.
segment.target: The server side configuration to enable Network Unlock also requires provisioning a 2048-bit RSA public/private key pair in the form of an X.509 certificate, and for the public key certificate to be distributed to the clients.

segment.source: This certificate must be managed and deployed through the Group Policy editor directly on a domain controller with at least a Domain Functional Level of Windows Server 2012.
segment.target: This certificate must be managed and deployed through the Group Policy editor directly on a domain controller with at least a Domain Functional Level of Windows Server 2012.

segment.source: This certificate is the public key that encrypts the intermediate network key (which is one of the two secrets required to unlock the drive; the other secret is stored in the TPM).
segment.target: This certificate is the public key that encrypts the intermediate network key (which is one of the two secrets required to unlock the drive; the other secret is stored in the TPM).

segment.source: bitlocker network unlock sequence
segment.target: bitlocker network unlock sequence

segment.source: Phases in the Network Unlock process
segment.target: Phases in the Network Unlock process

segment.source: The Windows boot manager detects that a Network Unlock protector exists in the BitLocker configuration.
segment.target: The Windows boot manager detects that a Network Unlock protector exists in the BitLocker configuration.

segment.source: The client computer uses its DHCP driver in the UEFI to obtain a valid IPv4 IP address.
segment.target: The client computer uses its DHCP driver in the UEFI to obtain a valid IPv4 IP address.

segment.source: The client computer broadcasts a vendor-specific DHCP request that contains the Network Key (a 256-bit intermediate key) and an AES-256 session key for the reply.
segment.target: The client computer broadcasts a vendor-specific DHCP request that contains the Network Key (a 256-bit intermediate key) and an AES-256 session key for the reply.

segment.source: Both of these keys are encrypted using the 2048-bit RSA Public Key of the Network Unlock certificate from the WDS server.
segment.target: Both of these keys are encrypted using the 2048-bit RSA Public Key of the Network Unlock certificate from the WDS server.

segment.source: The Network Unlock provider on the WDS server recognizes the vendor-specific request.
segment.target: The Network Unlock provider on the WDS server recognizes the vendor-specific request.

segment.source: The provider decrypts it with the WDS server’s BitLocker Network Unlock certificate RSA private key.
segment.target: The provider decrypts it with the WDS server’s BitLocker Network Unlock certificate RSA private key.

segment.source: The WDS provider then returns the network key encrypted with the session key using its own vendor-specific DHCP reply to the client computer.
segment.target: The WDS provider then returns the network key encrypted with the session key using its own vendor-specific DHCP reply to the client computer.

segment.source: This forms an intermediate key.
segment.target: This forms an intermediate key.

segment.source: The returned intermediate key is then combined with another local 256-bit intermediate key that can only be decrypted by the TPM.
segment.target: The returned intermediate key is then combined with another local 256-bit intermediate key that can only be decrypted by the TPM.

segment.source: This combined key is used to create an AES-256 key that unlocks the volume.
segment.target: This combined key is used to create an AES-256 key that unlocks the volume.

segment.source: Windows continues the boot sequence.
segment.target: Windows continues the boot sequence.

segment.source: Configure Network Unlock
segment.target: Configure Network Unlock

segment.source: The following steps allow an administrator to configure Network Unlock in a domain where the Domain Functional Level is at least Windows Server 2012.
segment.target: The following steps allow an administrator to configure Network Unlock in a domain where the Domain Functional Level is at least Windows Server 2012.

segment.source: Step One: Install the WDS Server role
segment.target: Step One: Install the WDS Server role

segment.source: The BitLocker Network Unlock feature will install the WDS role if it is not already installed.
segment.target: The BitLocker Network Unlock feature will install the WDS role if it is not already installed.

segment.source: If you want to install it separately before you install BitLocker Network Unlock you can use Server Manager or Windows PowerShell.
segment.target: If you want to install it separately before you install BitLocker Network Unlock you can use Server Manager or Windows PowerShell.

segment.source: To install the role using Server Manager, select the Windows Deployment Services role in Server Manager.
segment.target: To install the role using Server Manager, select the Windows Deployment Services role in Server Manager.

segment.source: To install the role using Windows PowerShell, use the following command:
segment.target: To install the role using Windows PowerShell, use the following command:

segment.source: You must configure the WDS server so that it can communicate with DHCP (and optionally Active Directory Doman Services) and the client computer.
segment.target: You must configure the WDS server so that it can communicate with DHCP (and optionally Active Directory Doman Services) and the client computer.

segment.source: You can do using the WDS management tool, wdsmgmt.msc, which starts the Windows Deployment Services Configuration Wizard.
segment.target: You can do using the WDS management tool, wdsmgmt.msc, which starts the Windows Deployment Services Configuration Wizard.

segment.source: Step Two: Confirm the WDS Service is running
segment.target: Step Two: Confirm the WDS Service is running

segment.source: To confirm the WDS service is running, use the Services Management Console or Windows PowerShell.
segment.target: To confirm the WDS service is running, use the Services Management Console or Windows PowerShell.

segment.source: To confirm the service is running in Services Management Console, open the console using services.msc and check the status of the Windows Deployment Services service.
segment.target: To confirm the service is running in Services Management Console, open the console using services.msc and check the status of the Windows Deployment Services service.

segment.source: To confirm the service is running using Windows PowerShell, use the following command:
segment.target: To confirm the service is running using Windows PowerShell, use the following command:

segment.source: Step Three: Install the Network Unlock feature
segment.target: Step Three: Install the Network Unlock feature

segment.source: To install the Network Unlock feature, use Server Manager or Windows PowerShell.
segment.target: To install the Network Unlock feature, use Server Manager or Windows PowerShell.

segment.source: To install the feature using Server Manager, select the BitLocker Network Unlock feature in the Server Manager console.
segment.target: To install the feature using Server Manager, select the BitLocker Network Unlock feature in the Server Manager console.

segment.source: To install the feature using Windows PowerShell, use the following command:
segment.target: To install the feature using Windows PowerShell, use the following command:

segment.source: Step Four: Create the Network Unlock certificate
segment.target: Step Four: Create the Network Unlock certificate

segment.source: Network Unlock can use imported certificates from an existing PKI infrastructure, or you can use a self-signed certificate.
segment.target: Network Unlock can use imported certificates from an existing PKI infrastructure, or you can use a self-signed certificate.

segment.source: To enroll a certificate from an existing certification authority (CA), do the following:
segment.target: To enroll a certificate from an existing certification authority (CA), do the following:

segment.source: Open Certificate Manager on the WDS server using certmgr.msc
segment.target: Open Certificate Manager on the WDS server using certmgr.msc

segment.source: Under the Certificates - Current User item, right-click Personal
segment.target: Under the Certificates - Current User item, right-click Personal

segment.source: Select All Tasks, then Request New Certificate
segment.target: Select All Tasks, then Request New Certificate

segment.source: Select Next when the Certificate Enrollment wizard opens
segment.target: Select Next when the Certificate Enrollment wizard opens

segment.source: Select Active Directory Enrollment Policy
segment.target: Select Active Directory Enrollment Policy

segment.source: Choose the certificate template created for Network Unlock on the Domain controller and select Enroll.
segment.target: Choose the certificate template created for Network Unlock on the Domain controller and select Enroll.

segment.source: When prompted for more information, add the following attribute to the certificate:
segment.target: When prompted for more information, add the following attribute to the certificate:

segment.source: Select the Subject Name pane and provide a friendly name value.
segment.target: Select the Subject Name pane and provide a friendly name value.

segment.source: It is suggested that this friendly name include information for the domain or organizational unit for the certificate.
segment.target: It is suggested that this friendly name include information for the domain or organizational unit for the certificate.

segment.source: For example "BitLocker Network Unlock Certificate for Contoso domain"
segment.target: For example "BitLocker Network Unlock Certificate for Contoso domain"

segment.source: Create the certificate.
segment.target: Create the certificate.

segment.source: Ensure the certificate appears in the Personal folder.
segment.target: Ensure the certificate appears in the Personal folder.

segment.source: Export the public key certificate for Network Unlock
segment.target: Export the public key certificate for Network Unlock

segment.source: Create a .cer file by right-clicking the previously created certificate, choosing All Tasks, then Export.
segment.target: Create a .cer file by right-clicking the previously created certificate, choosing All Tasks, then Export.

segment.source: Select No, do not export the private key.
segment.target: Select No, do not export the private key.

segment.source: Select DER encoded binary X.509 and complete exporting the certificate to a file.
segment.target: Select DER encoded binary X.509 and complete exporting the certificate to a file.

segment.source: Give the file a name such as BitLocker-NetworkUnlock.cer.
segment.target: Give the file a name such as BitLocker-NetworkUnlock.cer.

segment.source: Export the public key with a private key for Network Unlock
segment.target: Export the public key with a private key for Network Unlock

segment.source: Create a .pfx file by right-clicking the previously created certificate, choosing All Tasks, then Export.
segment.target: Create a .pfx file by right-clicking the previously created certificate, choosing All Tasks, then Export.

segment.source: Select Yes, export the private key.
segment.target: Select Yes, export the private key.

segment.source: Complete the wizard to create the .pfx file.
segment.target: Complete the wizard to create the .pfx file.

segment.source: To create a self-signed certificate, do the following:
segment.target: To create a self-signed certificate, do the following:

segment.source: Create a text file with an .inf extension.
segment.target: Create a text file with an .inf extension.

segment.source: For example, notepad.exe BitLocker-NetworkUnlock.inf
segment.target: For example, notepad.exe BitLocker-NetworkUnlock.inf

segment.source: Add the following contents to the previously created file:
segment.target: Add the following contents to the previously created file:

segment.source: Open an elevated command prompt and use the certreq tool to create a new certificate using the following command, specifying the full path to the file created previously, along with the file name:
segment.target: Open an elevated command prompt and use the certreq tool to create a new certificate using the following command, specifying the full path to the file created previously, along with the file name:

segment.source: Verify the previous command properly created the certificate by confirming the .cer file exists
segment.target: Verify the previous command properly created the certificate by confirming the .cer file exists

segment.source: Launch the Certificate Manager by running certmgr.msc
segment.target: Launch the Certificate Manager by running certmgr.msc

segment.source: Create a .pfx file by opening the Certificates – Current UserPersonalCertificates path in the navigation pane, right-clicking the previously imported certificate, selecting All Tasks, then Export.
segment.target: Create a .pfx file by opening the Certificates – Current UserPersonalCertificates path in the navigation pane, right-clicking the previously imported certificate, selecting All Tasks, then Export.

segment.source: Follow through the wizard to create the .pfx file.
segment.target: Follow through the wizard to create the .pfx file.

segment.source: Step Five: Deploy the private key and certificate to the WDS server
segment.target: Step Five: Deploy the private key and certificate to the WDS server

segment.source: With the certificate and key created, deploy them to the infrastructure to properly unlock systems.
segment.target: With the certificate and key created, deploy them to the infrastructure to properly unlock systems.

segment.source: To deploy the certificates, do the following:
segment.target: To deploy the certificates, do the following:

segment.source: On the WDS server, open a new MMC and add the certificates snap-in.
segment.target: On the WDS server, open a new MMC and add the certificates snap-in.

segment.source: Select the computer account and local computer when given the options.
segment.target: Select the computer account and local computer when given the options.

segment.source: Right-click the Certificates (Local Computer) - BitLocker Drive Encryption Network Unlock item, choose All Tasks, then Import
segment.target: Right-click the Certificates (Local Computer) - BitLocker Drive Encryption Network Unlock item, choose All Tasks, then Import

segment.source: In the File to Import dialog, choose the .pfx file created previously.
segment.target: In the File to Import dialog, choose the .pfx file created previously.

segment.source: Enter the password used to create the .pfx and complete the wizard.
segment.target: Enter the password used to create the .pfx and complete the wizard.

segment.source: Step Six: Configure Group Policy settings for Network Unlock
segment.target: Step Six: Configure Group Policy settings for Network Unlock

segment.source: With certificate and key deployed to the WDS server for Network Unlock, the final step is to use Group Policy settings to deploy the public key certificate to computers that you want to be able to unlock using the Network Unlock key.
segment.target: With certificate and key deployed to the WDS server for Network Unlock, the final step is to use Group Policy settings to deploy the public key certificate to computers that you want to be able to unlock using the Network Unlock key.

segment.source: Group Policy settings for BitLocker can be found under Computer ConfigurationAdministrative TemplatesWindows ComponentsBitLocker Drive Encryption using the Local Group Policy Editor or the Microsoft Management Console.
segment.target: Group Policy settings for BitLocker can be found under Computer ConfigurationAdministrative TemplatesWindows ComponentsBitLocker Drive Encryption using the Local Group Policy Editor or the Microsoft Management Console.

segment.source: The following steps describe how to enable the Group Policy setting that is a requirement for configuring Network Unlock.
segment.target: The following steps describe how to enable the Group Policy setting that is a requirement for configuring Network Unlock.

segment.source: Open Group Policy Management Console (gpmc.msc)
segment.target: Open Group Policy Management Console (gpmc.msc)

segment.source: Enable the policy Require additional authentication at startup and select the Require startup PIN with TPM option
segment.target: Enable the policy Require additional authentication at startup and select the Require startup PIN with TPM option

segment.source: Turn on BitLocker with TPM+PIN protectors on all domain-joined computers
segment.target: Turn on BitLocker with TPM+PIN protectors on all domain-joined computers

segment.source: The following steps describe how to deploy the required Group Policy setting:
segment.target: The following steps describe how to deploy the required Group Policy setting:

segment.source: Note: The Group Policy settings Allow network unlock at startup and Add Network Unlock Certificate were introduced in Windows Server 2012.
segment.target: Note: The Group Policy settings Allow network unlock at startup and Add Network Unlock Certificate were introduced in Windows Server 2012.

segment.source: Copy the .cer file created for Network Unlock to the domain controller
segment.target: Copy the .cer file created for Network Unlock to the domain controller

segment.source: On the domain controller, launch Group Policy Management Console (gpmc.msc)
segment.target: On the domain controller, launch Group Policy Management Console (gpmc.msc)

segment.source: Create a new Group Policy Object or modify an existing object to enable the Allow network unlock at startup setting.
segment.target: Create a new Group Policy Object or modify an existing object to enable the Allow network unlock at startup setting.

segment.source: Deploy the public certificate to clients
segment.target: Deploy the public certificate to clients

segment.source: Within Group Policy Management Console, navigate to the following location: Computer ConfigurationPoliciesWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsPublic Key PoliciesBitLocker Drive Encryption Network Unlock Certificate
segment.target: Within Group Policy Management Console, navigate to the following location: Computer ConfigurationPoliciesWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsPublic Key PoliciesBitLocker Drive Encryption Network Unlock Certificate

segment.source: Right-click the folder and choose Add Network Unlock Certificate
segment.target: Right-click the folder and choose Add Network Unlock Certificate

segment.source: Follow the wizard steps and import the .cer file that was copied earlier.
segment.target: Follow the wizard steps and import the .cer file that was copied earlier.

segment.source: Note: Only one network unlock certificate can be available at a time.
segment.target: Note: Only one network unlock certificate can be available at a time.

segment.source: If a new certificate is required, delete the current certificate before deploying a new one.
segment.target: If a new certificate is required, delete the current certificate before deploying a new one.

segment.source: The Network Unlock certificate is located in the HKEYLOCALMACHINESoftwarePoliciesMicrosoftSystemCertificatesFVENKP key on the client computer.
segment.target: The Network Unlock certificate is located in the HKEYLOCALMACHINESoftwarePoliciesMicrosoftSystemCertificatesFVENKP key on the client computer.

segment.source: Step Seven: Require TPM+PIN protectors at startup
segment.target: Step Seven: Require TPM+PIN protectors at startup

segment.source: An additional step is for enterprises to use TPM+PIN protectors for an extra level of security.
segment.target: An additional step is for enterprises to use TPM+PIN protectors for an extra level of security.

segment.source: To require TPM+PIN protectors in an environment, do the following:
segment.target: To require TPM+PIN protectors in an environment, do the following:

segment.source: Open Group Policy Management Console (gpmc.msc)
segment.target: Open Group Policy Management Console (gpmc.msc)

segment.source: Enable the policy Require additional authentication at startup and select the Require startup PIN with TPM option
segment.target: Enable the policy Require additional authentication at startup and select the Require startup PIN with TPM option

segment.source: Turn on BitLocker with TPM+PIN protectors on all domain-joined computers
segment.target: Turn on BitLocker with TPM+PIN protectors on all domain-joined computers

segment.source: Create the certificate template for Network Unlock
segment.target: Create the certificate template for Network Unlock

segment.source: The following steps detail how to create a certificate template for use with BitLocker Network Unlock.
segment.target: The following steps detail how to create a certificate template for use with BitLocker Network Unlock.

segment.source: A properly configured Active Directory Services Certification Authority can use this certificate to create and issue Network Unlock certificates.
segment.target: A properly configured Active Directory Services Certification Authority can use this certificate to create and issue Network Unlock certificates.

segment.source: Open the Certificates Template snap-in (certtmpl.msc).
segment.target: Open the Certificates Template snap-in (certtmpl.msc).

segment.source: Locate the User template.
segment.target: Locate the User template.

segment.source: Right-click the template name and select Duplicate Template
segment.target: Right-click the template name and select Duplicate Template

segment.source: On the Compatibility tab, change the Certification Authority and Certificate recipient fields to Windows Server 2012 and Windows 8respectively.
segment.target: On the Compatibility tab, change the Certification Authority and Certificate recipient fields to Windows Server 2012 and Windows 8respectively.

segment.source: Ensure the Show resulting changes dialog box is selected.
segment.target: Ensure the Show resulting changes dialog box is selected.

segment.source: Select the General tab of the template.
segment.target: Select the General tab of the template.

segment.source: The Template display name and Template name should clearly identify that the template will be used for Network Unlock.
segment.target: The Template display name and Template name should clearly identify that the template will be used for Network Unlock.

segment.source: Clear the checkbox for the Publish certificate in Active Directory option.
segment.target: Clear the checkbox for the Publish certificate in Active Directory option.

segment.source: Select the Request Handling tab.
segment.target: Select the Request Handling tab.

segment.source: Select Encryption from the Purpose drop down menu.
segment.target: Select Encryption from the Purpose drop down menu.

segment.source: Ensure the Allow private key to be exported option is selected.
segment.target: Ensure the Allow private key to be exported option is selected.

segment.source: Select the Cryptography tab.
segment.target: Select the Cryptography tab.

segment.source: Set the Minimum key size to 2048.
segment.target: Set the Minimum key size to 2048.

segment.source: (Any Microsoft cryptographic provider that supports RSA can be used for this template, but for simplicity and forward compatibility we recommend using the Microsoft Software Key Storage Provider.)
segment.target: (Any Microsoft cryptographic provider that supports RSA can be used for this template, but for simplicity and forward compatibility we recommend using the Microsoft Software Key Storage Provider.)

segment.source: Select the Requests must use one of the following providers option and clear all options except for the cryptography provider you selected, such as the Microsoft Software Key Storage Provider.
segment.target: Select the Requests must use one of the following providers option and clear all options except for the cryptography provider you selected, such as the Microsoft Software Key Storage Provider.

segment.source: Select the Subject Name tab.
segment.target: Select the Subject Name tab.

segment.source: Select Supply in the request.
segment.target: Select Supply in the request.

segment.source: Select OK if the certificate templates pop-up dialog appears.
segment.target: Select OK if the certificate templates pop-up dialog appears.

segment.source: Select the Issuance Requirements tab.
segment.target: Select the Issuance Requirements tab.

segment.source: Select both CA certificate manager approval and Valid existing certificate options.
segment.target: Select both CA certificate manager approval and Valid existing certificate options.

segment.source: Select the Extensions tab.
segment.target: Select the Extensions tab.

segment.source: Select Application Policies and choose Edit….
segment.target: Select Application Policies and choose Edit….

segment.source: In the Edit Application Policies Extension options dialog box, select Client Authentication, Encrypting File System, and Secure Email and choose Remove.
segment.target: In the Edit Application Policies Extension options dialog box, select Client Authentication, Encrypting File System, and Secure Email and choose Remove.

segment.source: On the Edit Application Policies Extension dialog box, select Add.
segment.target: On the Edit Application Policies Extension dialog box, select Add.

segment.source: On the Add Application Policy dialog box, select New.
segment.target: On the Add Application Policy dialog box, select New.

segment.source: In the New Application Policy dialog box enter the following information in the space provided and then click OK to create the BitLocker Network Unlock application policy:
segment.target: In the New Application Policy dialog box enter the following information in the space provided and then click OK to create the BitLocker Network Unlock application policy:

segment.source: Select the newly created BitLocker Network Unlock application policy and select OK
segment.target: Select the newly created BitLocker Network Unlock application policy and select OK

segment.source: With the Extensions tab still open, select the Edit Key Usage Extension dialog, select the Allow key exchange only with key encryption (key encipherment) option.
segment.target: With the Extensions tab still open, select the Edit Key Usage Extension dialog, select the Allow key exchange only with key encryption (key encipherment) option.

segment.source: Select the Make this extension critical option.
segment.target: Select the Make this extension critical option.

segment.source: Select the Security tab.
segment.target: Select the Security tab.

segment.source: Confirm that the Domain Admins group has been granted Enroll permission
segment.target: Confirm that the Domain Admins group has been granted Enroll permission

segment.source: Select OK to complete configuration of the template.
segment.target: Select OK to complete configuration of the template.

segment.source: To add the Network Unlock template to the Certification Authority, open the Certification Authority snap-in (certsrv.msc).
segment.target: To add the Network Unlock template to the Certification Authority, open the Certification Authority snap-in (certsrv.msc).

segment.source: Right-click the Certificate Templates item and choose New, Certificate Template to issue.
segment.target: Right-click the Certificate Templates item and choose New, Certificate Template to issue.

segment.source: Select the previously created BitLocker Network Unlock certificate.
segment.target: Select the previously created BitLocker Network Unlock certificate.

segment.source: After adding the Network Unlock template to the Certification Authority, this certificate can be used to configure BitLocker Network Unlock.
segment.target: After adding the Network Unlock template to the Certification Authority, this certificate can be used to configure BitLocker Network Unlock.

segment.source: Subnet policy configuration files on WDS Server (Optional)
segment.target: Subnet policy configuration files on WDS Server (Optional)

segment.source: By default, all clients with the correct Network Unlock Certificate and valid Network Unlock protectors that have wired access to a Network Unlock-enabled WDS server via DHCP are unlocked by the server.
segment.target: By default, all clients with the correct Network Unlock Certificate and valid Network Unlock protectors that have wired access to a Network Unlock-enabled WDS server via DHCP are unlocked by the server.

segment.source: A subnet policy configuration file on the WDS server can be created to limit which subnet(s) Network Unlock clients can use to unlock.
segment.target: A subnet policy configuration file on the WDS server can be created to limit which subnet(s) Network Unlock clients can use to unlock.

segment.source: The configuration file, called bde-network-unlock.ini, must be located in the same directory as the Network Unlock provider DLL and it applies to both IPv6 and IPv4 DHCP implementations.
segment.target: The configuration file, called bde-network-unlock.ini, must be located in the same directory as the Network Unlock provider DLL and it applies to both IPv6 and IPv4 DHCP implementations.

segment.source: If the subnet configuration policy becomes corrupted, the provider will fail and stop responding to requests.
segment.target: If the subnet configuration policy becomes corrupted, the provider will fail and stop responding to requests.

segment.source: The subnet policy configuration file must use a “SUBNETS” section to identify the specific subnets.
segment.target: The subnet policy configuration file must use a “SUBNETS” section to identify the specific subnets.

segment.source: The named subnets may then be used to specify restrictions in certificate subsections.
segment.target: The named subnets may then be used to specify restrictions in certificate subsections.

segment.source: Subnets are defined as simple name-value pairs, in the common INI format, where each subnet has its own line, with the name on the left of the equals sign, and the subnet identified on the right of the equal sign as a Classless Inter-Domain Routing (CIDR) address or range.
segment.target: Subnets are defined as simple name-value pairs, in the common INI format, where each subnet has its own line, with the name on the left of the equals sign, and the subnet identified on the right of the equal sign as a Classless Inter-Domain Routing (CIDR) address or range.

segment.source: The key word “ENABLED” is disallowed for subnet names.
segment.target: The key word “ENABLED” is disallowed for subnet names.

segment.source: To disallow the use of a certificate altogether, its subnet list may contain the line “DISABLED".
segment.target: To disallow the use of a certificate altogether, its subnet list may contain the line “DISABLED".

segment.source: Turning off Network Unlock
segment.target: Turning off Network Unlock

segment.source: To turn off the unlock server, the PXE provider can be unregistered from the WDS server or uninstalled altogether.
segment.target: To turn off the unlock server, the PXE provider can be unregistered from the WDS server or uninstalled altogether.

segment.source: However, to stop clients from creating Network Unlock protectors the Allow Network Unlock at startup Group Policy setting should be disabled.
segment.target: However, to stop clients from creating Network Unlock protectors the Allow Network Unlock at startup Group Policy setting should be disabled.

segment.source: When this policy setting is updated to disabled on client computers any Network Unlock key protectors on the computer will be deleted.
segment.target: When this policy setting is updated to disabled on client computers any Network Unlock key protectors on the computer will be deleted.

segment.source: Alternatively, the BitLocker Network Unlock certificate policy can be deleted on the domain controller to accomplish the same task for an entire domain.
segment.target: Alternatively, the BitLocker Network Unlock certificate policy can be deleted on the domain controller to accomplish the same task for an entire domain.

segment.source: Note: Removing the FVENKP certificate store that contains the Network Unlock certificate and key on the WDS server will also effectively disable the server’s ability to respond to unlock requests for that certificate.
segment.target: Note: Removing the FVENKP certificate store that contains the Network Unlock certificate and key on the WDS server will also effectively disable the server’s ability to respond to unlock requests for that certificate.

segment.source: However, this is seen as an error condition and is not a supported or recommended method for turning off the Network Unlock server.
segment.target: However, this is seen as an error condition and is not a supported or recommended method for turning off the Network Unlock server.

segment.source: Update Network Unlock certificates
segment.target: Update Network Unlock certificates

segment.source: To update the certificates used by Network Unlock, administrators need to import or generate the new certificate for the server and then update the Network Unlock certificate Group Policy setting on the domain controller.
segment.target: To update the certificates used by Network Unlock, administrators need to import or generate the new certificate for the server and then update the Network Unlock certificate Group Policy setting on the domain controller.

segment.source: Troubleshoot Network Unlock
segment.target: Troubleshoot Network Unlock

segment.source: Troubleshooting Network Unlock issues begins by verifying the environment.
segment.target: Troubleshooting Network Unlock issues begins by verifying the environment.

segment.source: Many times, a small configuration issue will be the root cause of the failure.
segment.target: Many times, a small configuration issue will be the root cause of the failure.

segment.source: Items to verify include:
segment.target: Items to verify include:

segment.source: Verify client hardware is UEFI-based and is on firmware version is 2.3.1 and that the UEFI firmware is in native mode without a Compatibility Support Module (CSM) for BIOS mode enabled.
segment.target: Verify client hardware is UEFI-based and is on firmware version is 2.3.1 and that the UEFI firmware is in native mode without a Compatibility Support Module (CSM) for BIOS mode enabled.

segment.source: Do this by checking that the firmware does not have an option enabled such as "Legacy mode" or "Compatibility mode" or that the firmware does not appear to be in a BIOS-like mode.
segment.target: Do this by checking that the firmware does not have an option enabled such as "Legacy mode" or "Compatibility mode" or that the firmware does not appear to be in a BIOS-like mode.

segment.source: All required roles and services are installed and started
segment.target: All required roles and services are installed and started

segment.source: Public and private certificates have been published and are in the proper certificate containers.
segment.target: Public and private certificates have been published and are in the proper certificate containers.

segment.source: The presence of the Network Unlock certificate can be verified in the Microsoft Management Console (MMC.exe) on the WDS server with the certificate snap-ins for the local computer enabled.
segment.target: The presence of the Network Unlock certificate can be verified in the Microsoft Management Console (MMC.exe) on the WDS server with the certificate snap-ins for the local computer enabled.

segment.source: The client certificate can be verified by checking the registry key HKEYLOCALMACHINESoftwarePoliciesMicrosoftSystemCertificatesFVENKP on the client computer.
segment.target: The client certificate can be verified by checking the registry key HKEYLOCALMACHINESoftwarePoliciesMicrosoftSystemCertificatesFVENKP on the client computer.

segment.source: Group policy for Network Unlock is enabled and linked to the appropriate domains
segment.target: Group policy for Network Unlock is enabled and linked to the appropriate domains

segment.source: Verify group policy is reaching the clients properly.
segment.target: Verify group policy is reaching the clients properly.

segment.source: This can be done using the GPRESULT.exe or RSOP.msc utilities.
segment.target: This can be done using the GPRESULT.exe or RSOP.msc utilities.

segment.source: Verify the Network (Certificate Based) protector is listed on the client.
segment.target: Verify the Network (Certificate Based) protector is listed on the client.

segment.source: This can be done using either manage-bde or Windows PowerShell cmdlets.
segment.target: This can be done using either manage-bde or Windows PowerShell cmdlets.

segment.source: For example the following command will list the key protectors currently configured on the C: drive of the lcoal computer:
segment.target: For example the following command will list the key protectors currently configured on the C: drive of the lcoal computer:

segment.source: Note: Use the output of manage-bde along with the WDS debug log to determine if the proper certificate thumbprint is being used for Network Unlock
segment.target: Note: Use the output of manage-bde along with the WDS debug log to determine if the proper certificate thumbprint is being used for Network Unlock

segment.source: Files to gather when troubleshooting BitLocker Network Unlock include:
segment.target: Files to gather when troubleshooting BitLocker Network Unlock include:

segment.source: The Windows event logs.
segment.target: The Windows event logs.

segment.source: Specifically the BitLocker event logs and the Microsoft-Windows-Deployment-Services-Diagnostics-Debug log
segment.target: Specifically the BitLocker event logs and the Microsoft-Windows-Deployment-Services-Diagnostics-Debug log

segment.source: Debug logging is turned off by default for the WDS server role, so you will need to enable it first.
segment.target: Debug logging is turned off by default for the WDS server role, so you will need to enable it first.

segment.source: You can use either of the following two methods to turn on WDS debug logging.
segment.target: You can use either of the following two methods to turn on WDS debug logging.

segment.source: Start an elevated command prompt and run the following command:
segment.target: Start an elevated command prompt and run the following command:

segment.source: Open Event Viewer on the WDS server.
segment.target: Open Event Viewer on the WDS server.

segment.source: In the left pane, click Applications and Services Logs, click Microsoft, click Windows, click Deployment-Services-Diagnostics, and then click Debug.
segment.target: In the left pane, click Applications and Services Logs, click Microsoft, click Windows, click Deployment-Services-Diagnostics, and then click Debug.

segment.source: In the right pane, click Enable Log.
segment.target: In the right pane, click Enable Log.

segment.source: The DHCP subnet configuration file (if one exists).
segment.target: The DHCP subnet configuration file (if one exists).

segment.source: The output of the BitLocker status on the volume, this can be gathered into a text file using manage-bde -status or Get-BitLockerVolume in Windows PowerShell
segment.target: The output of the BitLocker status on the volume, this can be gathered into a text file using manage-bde -status or Get-BitLockerVolume in Windows PowerShell

segment.source: Network Monitor capture on the server hosting the WDS role, filtered by client IP address
segment.target: Network Monitor capture on the server hosting the WDS role, filtered by client IP address

segment.source: Configure Network Unlock Group Policy settings on earlier versions
segment.target: Configure Network Unlock Group Policy settings on earlier versions

segment.source: Network Unlock and the accompanying Group Policy settings were introduced in Windows Server 2012 but can be deployed using operating systems running Windows Server 2008 R2 and Windows Server 2008.
segment.target: Network Unlock and the accompanying Group Policy settings were introduced in Windows Server 2012 but can be deployed using operating systems running Windows Server 2008 R2 and Windows Server 2008.

segment.source: Requirements
segment.target: Requirements

segment.source: The server hosting WDS must be running any of the server operating systems designated in the Applies To list at the beginning of this topic.
segment.target: The server hosting WDS must be running any of the server operating systems designated in the Applies To list at the beginning of this topic.

segment.source: Client computers must be running any of the client operating systems designated in the Applies To list at the beginning of this topic.
segment.target: Client computers must be running any of the client operating systems designated in the Applies To list at the beginning of this topic.

segment.source: The following steps can be used to configure Network Unlock on these older systems.
segment.target: The following steps can be used to configure Network Unlock on these older systems.

segment.source: Step One: Install the WDS Server role
segment.target: Step One: Install the WDS Server role

segment.source: Step Two: Confirm the WDS Service is running
segment.target: Step Two: Confirm the WDS Service is running

segment.source: Step Three: Install the Network Unlock feature
segment.target: Step Three: Install the Network Unlock feature

segment.source: Step Four: Create the Network Unlock certificate
segment.target: Step Four: Create the Network Unlock certificate

segment.source: Step Five: Deploy the private key and certificate to the WDS server
segment.target: Step Five: Deploy the private key and certificate to the WDS server

segment.source: Step Six: Configure registry settings for Network Unlock
segment.target: Step Six: Configure registry settings for Network Unlock

segment.source: Apply the registry settings by running the following certutil script on each computer running any of the client operating systems designated in the Applies To list at the beginning of this topic.
segment.target: Apply the registry settings by running the following certutil script on each computer running any of the client operating systems designated in the Applies To list at the beginning of this topic.

segment.source: certutil -f -grouppolicy -addstore FVE_NKP BitLocker-NetworkUnlock.cer reg add "HKLM\SOFTWARE\Policies\Microsoft\FVE" /v OSManageNKP /t REG_DWORD /d 1 /f reg add "HKLM\SOFTWARE\Policies\Microsoft\FVE" /v UseAdvancedStartup /t REG_DWORD /d 1 /f reg add "HKLM\SOFTWARE\Policies\Microsoft\FVE" /v UsePIN /t REG_DWORD /d 2 /f reg add "HKLM\SOFTWARE\Policies\Microsoft\FVE" /v UseTPMPIN /t REG_DWORD /d 2 /f reg add "HKLM\SOFTWARE\Policies\Microsoft\FVE" /v UseTPM /t REG_DWORD /d 2 /f reg add "HKLM\SOFTWARE\Policies\Microsoft\FVE" /v UseTPMKey /t REG_DWORD /d 2 /f reg add "HKLM\SOFTWARE\Policies\Microsoft\FVE" /v UseTPMKeyPIN /t REG_DWORD /d 2 /f
segment.target: certutil -f -grouppolicy -addstore FVE_NKP BitLocker-NetworkUnlock.cer reg add "HKLM\SOFTWARE\Policies\Microsoft\FVE" /v OSManageNKP /t REG_DWORD /d 1 /f reg add "HKLM\SOFTWARE\Policies\Microsoft\FVE" /v UseAdvancedStartup /t REG_DWORD /d 1 /f reg add "HKLM\SOFTWARE\Policies\Microsoft\FVE" /v UsePIN /t REG_DWORD /d 2 /f reg add "HKLM\SOFTWARE\Policies\Microsoft\FVE" /v UseTPMPIN /t REG_DWORD /d 2 /f reg add "HKLM\SOFTWARE\Policies\Microsoft\FVE" /v UseTPM /t REG_DWORD /d 2 /f reg add "HKLM\SOFTWARE\Policies\Microsoft\FVE" /v UseTPMKey /t REG_DWORD /d 2 /f reg add "HKLM\SOFTWARE\Policies\Microsoft\FVE" /v UseTPMKeyPIN /t REG_DWORD /d 2 /f

segment.source: Create the Network Unlock certificate
segment.target: Create the Network Unlock certificate

segment.source: Deploy the private key and certificate to the WDS server
segment.target: Deploy the private key and certificate to the WDS server

segment.source: Create the certificate template for Network Unlock
segment.target: Create the certificate template for Network Unlock

segment.source: Require TPM+PIN protectors at startup
segment.target: Require TPM+PIN protectors at startup
